description: 1927, in the book The Midnight Folk by John Masefield.

verbs.description: scrobble (third-person singular simple present scrobbles, present participle scrobbling, simple past and past participle scrobbled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To waylay, kidnap or steal.
examples: They've tried to scrobble another clergyman who was walking into Tatchester from Tineton.

description: From the name of the Internet service Audioscrobbler, probably a nonce coinage unrelated to etymology 1.

entries.meaning: A datum or the aggregate data collected by this means.

verbs.description: scrobble (third-person singular simple present scrobbles, present participle scrobbling, simple past and past participle scrobbled)

entries.meaning: (Internet slang) To publish one's media consumption habits to the Internet via software, in order to track when and how often certain items are played.
